PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Governments in Australia shows that:
General Revenue Grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83.
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent.
The increase in grants to State governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent.
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program.
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Collard (from 23 citizens), Crichton-Browne (from 37 citizens), Lewis (from nine citizens) and Robertson (from 16 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Haines (from 41 citizens), Macklin (from 21 citizens) and Robert Ray (from 38 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Student Residential Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the reduction in the subsidy to tertiary student residential colleges of twenty-five per cent announced in the Federal Budget will:

1. Increase the financial hardship already being experienced by Australian students. The cut in subsidies to colleges will undoubtedly increase fees for that accommodation in 1984. Many students will be forced out of tertiary education as they will not be able to meet these increased costs particularly as the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme only gained a maximum increase of $2.80 per week in the Federal Budget.

2. Decrease access to education for country students. Many country students live in college accommodation either to attend tertiary institutions in the metropolitan area or in regional centres. The cut in the subsidy to residential colleges will even futher disadvantage this group of students who already have comparatively low participation rates in tertiary education.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Senate to ensure:
(1) That the full subsidy to student college accommodation is immediately restored.
(2) That the Federal Government assume financial responsibility for all student college accommodation to prevent the planned closures of colleges in Victoria.
(3) That two student representatives are appointed to the committee of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reviewing student housing.

(4) That new forms of college accommodation are investigated which would be more appropriate to the needs of the current student population, i.e., accommodation appropriate for students with dependant children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Friendly Societies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned, being Electors in the State of NSW, respectfully submit that the Government review its intention to tax Friendly Societies after so many years of service to the community at large.
And in faith your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5.They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 49 citizens) and Robertson (from 180 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submits that: Although many occurrences of sexual harassment in the work force have been reported to various State government authorities, such as the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity, the real incidence of sexual intimidation in employment will not be known, or countered, until a national policy towards sexual harassment is determined and implemented.
We therefore submit that:

1. The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation be commissioned to conduct a nation-wide study of discrimination based on sex, both in the private sector and the Public Service, with a view to advising the Government on the development of national policy.
2. The major priority of such a study should be to determine a legally- enforceable definition of sexual harassment.

3. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should bring forward in Parliament legislation, arising from such a study, to outlaw discrimination and intimidation in employment based on sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to territorial or local government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of territorial or local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth. That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commemorative Postage Stamps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That to date no postage stamps have been issued to commemorate the services of Australian Forces in Korea and Vietnam.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should seek and support the issue of such commemorative stamps.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Welfare Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That there is grave cause for concern in the Australian community at the continuing sensationalist media and political campaign directed against the humanitarian and socially just effects of the Welfare State (most recently exemplified by the front-page article 'One in 4 get Welfare Hand' in the Melbourne Herald of Monday, 3rd October 1983).

That, whilst enlarging public awareness of the critical social problems facing our community, such articles tend to paint the victims of our social system as worthless parasites living off the work force.

1. We believe that the 635,000 persons receiving unemployment benefits at the end of June 1983 deserve full support from the Commonwealth, and that the 85,104 persons receiving sickness and special benefits deserve society's sympathy rather than castigation.

2. We also believe that the 2,011,542 persons receiving age, invalid, wife and widow pensions, supporting parent benefits and sheltered employment allowances at the end of June 1983 deserve help from the Commonwealth.

3. We affirm that it is the time-honoured and moral right of Australians to receive assistance in times of distress and hardship, and we remind the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia of its profound responsibility to safeguard and enhance the dignity and well-being of its citizens.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Manual Assistance Centre, Parkes
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposal of Telecom Australia to close the Manual Assistance Centre at Parkes will severely disadvantage the Parkes community by:
(i) the loss of current employment and future employment opportunities and consequent loss of income to the district
(ii) loss of local 24 hour emergency service
(iii) loss of local knowledge of telephonists being available to telephone users when traffic is routed to a telephone exchange anywhere in the State
(iv) the loss of a local and personalized service provided especially to the aged and disabled

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senate will call on the Government to halt the closure pending a full and open enquiry into the needs and desires of affected subscribers and the full economic and social effect of the closure on this district, rural telephone subscribers and Telecom Australia employees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1 per cent of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other States.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.

As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should
Use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $40 per day) against insured Queenslanders.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (PROHIBITION OF EXPORTATION OF NUCLEAR MATERIALS) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the exportation of nuclear materials for purposes connected therewith.
Bill presented by Senator Chipp, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leader of the Australian Democrats)-(10.07)-by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This legislation provides for an absolute prohibition on the export of uranium from Australia. It is similar to legislation I introduced in 1983 but which was defeated when the Australian Labor Party Government and the Opposition combined to vote against the Australian Democrats. This legislation is being introduced because the nuclear issue is of such fundamental importance to the future of humanity that the mere vote of the major political parties cannot be allowed to perpetuate a cover-up.

Australia's reserves of uranium make us a major participant in the world's nuclear fuel cycle. Uranium is good for only two things: Fuel for nuclear power reactors or fuel for nuclear bombs. Any responsible examination of whether or not Australia should export uranium must fully consider what uranium is used for , and what the implications of that use are. The Australian Democrats are in no doubt that uranium mining can never be justified. The nuclear power industry began forty years ago with the promise of electricity 'too cheap to meter'. It is now too expensive to produce.

In the United States, the home of the nuclear industry, no new reactors have been ordered since 1978. All reactors ordered since 1974 have been cancelled. In January of this year there were three shocks to the nuclear industry in the United States that demonstrate beyond doubt its ailing character. A reactor in Illinois completed at a cost of $3.7 billion was denied an operating licence because of a complete lack of confidence in its quality control. The Marble Hill reactor in Indiana was cancelled despite being half completed at a cost of $2.5 billion. Ohio's Zimmer plant, all but finished at a cost of $1.7 billion, is to be converted to coal. The poor economics of nuclear power are crippling the industry; but not only in the United States. The French nuclear industry, a state-run bureaucracy, has often been cited as a successful example of nuclear power's benefits. It is massively in debt, however. At the end of 1982 Electricite de France was $19 billion in the red.

The message is clear. Nuclear power cannot stand up by itself in the market- place. Without enormous government subsidies-at least $40 billion in the United States, and underwriting in France-it would not survive. The so-called free- marketeers of the major parties should think about this. Nuclear power will not be missed. Its contribution to the provision of energy for our society is, at best, minimal. In the United States nuclear power delivers less energy to people than that provided by firewood. In fact wood's contribution is twice that of nuclear power. In France nuclear power provides only one-quarter of that nation' s electricity generation. In the developing nations it provides less than 5 per cent of their electricity. No one in the world will suffer from any reduction in living standards if nuclear power is replaced by the cheapest sources of energy- namely, conservation and renewable resources.

The nuclear industry, despite the fact that it has been producing highly radioactive waste for some 30 years, has developed or adopted no permanent waste disposal system. That is an international scandal. It is a severe indictment on all those involved in the industry. The nuclear power industry has many other failings. Consider, for example, the leaks of radiation into the environment from operating reactors and the lax security surrounding the nuclear industry that has allowed many tonnes of bomb-useable material to have gone missing. These facts must be examined when we consider the issue of Australian uranium. We cannot blindly export uranium and ignore the fact that this country's actions will be interpreted as supporting an economically inefficient and dangerous industry. That is a situation that the Australian Democrats cannot countenance.

The spread of nuclear power spreads nuclear bombs. It provides the materials, the technology and the personnel that, when mixed with the intent, can develop a nuclear arsenal. In fact, an international nuclear arsenal has been developed. A modern nuclear power plant produces enough plutonium each year for dozens of atomic bombs. The world's nuclear plants-some 211 operating in Western countries -produce in total about 40 metric tons of separated plutonium each year. That is enough for some 5,000 to 20,000 nuclear bombs each year. That plutonium is ready for immediate use now-by governments or terrorists. That is not all the plutonium produced by reactors, however. Each year another 175 tonnes remains unseparated from reactor waste. If separated, that would be enough for over 27, 000 nuclear bombs. It is there for terrorists and crazy governments to use. However, nuclear bombs do not even need separated plutonium. Robert W. Seldon, of the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, a nuclear bomb laboratory, wrote in 1977:
. . . an entirely credible national nuclear explosives capability could be constructed using only reactor grade plutonium.

Just to prove it, the United States announced in August 1977 that such a bomb had been successfully exploded. As noted above, there is enough of this material for some 27,000 nuclear bombs in 1982 alone. Nothing can safeguard these potential arsenals. We must recognise that the elaborate international safeguards system can do no more than detect a diversion of 'peaceful' nuclear material into bombs, and warn people about it. It cannot prevent a diversion from occurring. International safeguards, in particular the International Atomic Energy Agency, are not policemen preventing the diversions. They are mere auditors. The IAEA has only 132 inspectors to cover 854 facilities. The safeguards that those people administer allow a 1-1.5 per cent loss of plutonium or highly enriched uranium. This material unaccounted for-MUF-alone could be to build a small arsenal of weapons. The Roxby Downs uranium mine-the world's largest, and approved by this Labor Government-even if it was put under the strictest safeguards, would leak into the world enough plutonium for 3,800 nuclear bombs. We in the Democrats find both the morality and the practical considerations of that totally abhorrent for a country like Australia. There can be no justification for such a situation.

The greatest problem with proliferation is identifying a military diversion. It needs to be clearly seen. That problem can be solved by ending uranium mining, uranium enrichment, reprocessing and nuclear power programs. This would leave any nuclear activity with an unmistakable military intent. Such blatant motives are more easily identified, more politically repugnant and thus more easily opposed. It will not make proliferation impossible but certainly will make it much more difficult than at present. That is an improvement towards a safer world that all people should support. Because of these facts the end of the nuclear industry is both a necessary and sufficient condition to end nuclear proliferation.

This Bill provides for an end to uranium mining in Australia. That is the first of a number of steps the Democrats will propose to end Australia's involvement in the cycle of nuclear madness. To do nothing about the crisis the world faces from nuclear bombs, the uneconomic nature of nuclear power and the environmental risks of both, is as good as aiding the problem. We believe this Bill to be a step in the right direction. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Haines) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 so as to give further protection to consumers in respect of defective motor vehicles.
Bill presented by Senator Haines, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

On 17 November 1982 I raised in the Senate the question of whether or not Australia needed to follow the example of some United States of America States and introduce legislation to protect consumers who, having bought a faulty car, discover that they are basically stuck with a 'lemon'. This Bill is aimed at providing protection for those people. I must stress that it is not an attack on all the importers, manufacturers and distributors of cars in Australia. Most of them are conscious of the need to maintain the integrity of a brand name by giving prompt and effective service on a car proved to be faulty. Indeed, the 1982 annual report of the Victorian Director of Consumer Affairs notes:

By 1980 it was apparent that a trend had developed whereby several manufacturers were offering genuine assistance towards the rectification of mechanical or paint faults that perhaps could have originated from manufacture.

In other words, some were prepared to take their responsibilities even beyond the warranty period. That is, of course, commendable but it does not solve the problem. Some authorised service agents are simply not prepared to accept fully their responsibilities even during the warranty period. Purchasing a vehicle represents a high proportion of the expenditure, income and savings of most householders. The ability of these people to seek proper redress when the vehicle purchased will not perform the functions for which it was intended, or does not exhibit the characteristics that were claimed for it, must not be dependent on the good will of the manufacturer alone. I believe that the purchaser of a new motor vehicle is entitled to be protected by the law and not subject to the whims of a manufacturer or distributor.

Most people know of someone who has or claims to have bought a 'dud' car, even if they have not suffered that fate themselves. Most of us therefore have seen the suffering and humiliation experienced by people who have innocently parted with thousands of dollars in the vain expectation that this would entitle them to a period of trouble-free car ownership. The joy and pride of ownership quickly evaporate as people suffer the extremely frustrating experience of being fobbed off with excuses such as: 'They all make that noise'; 'It does not make a noise when we drive it'; 'Change your driving style'; 'Ignore it, it will probably go away soon'; or 'They all do that'. I point out that these excuses have been passed on to me by people suffering from these problems. It should not be almost impossible to get compensation in circumstances where a genuine complaint exists.

The example I cited in November 1982 was an American example, and an extreme one. It concerned a man who fought, for 18 months, a vain battle to have his car repaired satisfactorily. The faults he complained of included the car collecting seven inches of water after a rainstorm, the electrical system failing repeatedly, the paint peeling, the parking brake pedal coming off, the manual transmission repeatedly popping out of second gear and going into neutral, and an assortment of lesser faults. Despite the seriousness of his complaints the car sat in the dealer's yard for transmission repairs for 135 days over a period of 18 months. It was his case which was a major factor in leading the Connecticut legislature to pass its own legislation to ensure that manufacturers , distributors and authorised agents accepted the fact that their responsibility to a customer went beyond merely selling a person a car.

While all cases may not be as extreme as the American example I have just cited , there are nevertheless in Australia sufficient problems for the major source of consumer complaints to be the broad area relating to motor vehicles. This comprises the purchase of new and used vehicles, repairs and servicing, and other motor vehicle products. The major reason for complaint is the poor quality of a product or service. Since I raised this matter in 1982 I have been contacted by many people, a number of them producing vast quantities of documents, letters and so on to manufacturers, all of whom have complained that they have not received the satisfaction that they saw as their right following the purchase of a new and generally expensive motor vehicle.

These amendments will give people with a legitimate complaint the right to compensation. They will compel manufacturers and distributors to deal properly with people who have bought a motor vehicle that does not function properly. They will put pressure on the manufacturer to market products which work and to make a determined effort to quickly remedy faults that may occur. If these amendments are passed, it will no longer be in the interests of the manufacturer to ask for the vehicle to be returned again and again as a tactic to wear down the unfortunate purchaser. It will be possible for a person to buy a vehicle with some certainly that the buyer will not be forced to be the reluctant owner of a 'lemon' on wheels. It will give the manufacturers an enormous incentive to make warranty claims that are feasible and to exercise the most stringent quality control measures over the motor vehicles that they produce.

Furthermore, a motor vehicle purchaser would be entitled to redress if the warranty on that vehicle were still in force and within one year from the date on which the vehicle was first supplied to the consumer. The redress would be in the form of a new motor vehicle or financial reimbursement after depreciation had been taken into account. The consumer would be entitled to redress if, on not less than four occasions, a particular defect to which the warranty were applicable was not remedied, or if the motor vehicle had been out of service for more than 30 days-whether in a continuous period or not-by reason of any defect to which the warranty applied.

I repeat, this Bill is not to be taken as an attack on motor vehicle importers and manufacturers. It will, however, compel those who do not already do so to act in a socially responsible manner, that is, to force them all to do what some already do. Sub-section 74GA (4) gives manufacturers and not the comsumer the option of choosing between the supply of a new vehicle and the making of a refund. This appears to be the position under similar State laws in the United States of America. Although I note that the United States Federal law relating to consumer products generally provides that the warrantor 'must permit the consumer to elect either a refund for or replacement without charge of such product or part', in this instance I think it is reasonable that the manufacturer should have the option-especially as a comparable car may not be available where a new model has come out. Further, the depreciation or damage may be such as to make it unreasonable that the manufacturer should be required to provide a new vehicle.

Sub-section 74GA (7) has been included because it is difficult, if not impossible, to foresee and provide for all the problems that can arise out of the making of a refund or the supply of a new motor vehicle. It therefore seems to be appropriate and wise to rest in the Federal court wide powers to declare or adjust rights and liabilities.

By imposing legal obligations on manufacturers and importers, these amendments will basically reduce the element of risk currently entailed when a consumer purchases a new motor vehicle. They will protect consumers by imposing a real social responsibility on manufacturers and importers. I do not oppose the profit motive. It is, after all, the driving force of a basically free enterprise economy. Modern society, however, has also achieved some progress in social responsibility. We can no longer rely on producers motivated solely by profit necessarily or voluntarily to do the right thing. Experience suggests that while many do, many do not. It is time, therefore, that the law protected the consumer or purchaser of a new motor vehicle. My amendments will achieve that aim and I commend the Bill to the Senate and look forward to its early passage.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) VALIDATION BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 December 1983, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Validation Bill 1983 was before the Senate, but not debated, at the end of last year. As circumstances stand at the moment, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.
(Quorum formed)
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day, for the first day of sitting after 1 May 1984.

I would like to speak to this motion at least in some detail as I think it is necessary to explain the position. It appears, at least to those of us on this side of the Senate, quite extraordinary that the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) have persisted with the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Validation Bill 1983. It was brought before the Senate on the last day of the sitting last year but was not debated. It was evident that the Government was not aware of the real difficulties and real problems of the industry to which these increased costs were to apply. Consequently it was hoped that a proper measure of consultation would, at least in part, resolve the issue .

Taking advantage of the recess and of the fact that the Government had not pursued the legislation late last year such consultation has occurred. Indeed committees have been set up to investigate the area of cost effectiveness of meat inspection-indeed of the industry itself. As the Minister has said the Interim Inspection Policy Council is to carry out as a matter of priority an examination of the financial and economic aspects of the current recovery of inspection costs in the export meat industry. The Minister has asked that the Council's report be available by the end of April. That is a reasonably short period and to us it seems most inappropriate, indeed not understandable, that the Government would want to pursue this legislation which would impose an extraordinarily heavy cost structure on the industry in the absence of an opinion to be formed by the Council and the result of widespread investigations and hearings which are to take place across Australia in Brisbane, Sydney and Hobart during the week commencing 12 March 1984 and in Perth, Adelaide and Melbourne during the following week. It will be a widespread and in-depth inquiry into a whole range of issues that relate to the export inspection of meat, to the calibre of that inspection and to its cost. It will relate that to the industry in the current circumstances in which it finds itself and indeed in the circumstances in which it has to compete in a highly competitive and, at the moment, somewhat down-graded meat export industry.

This legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives as long ago as last September, I believe, and it represents a desperate attempt by a Government, which at that stage was ill-informed, apparently to head off a legal challenge by the industry. Much more particularly, the legislation was evidence of the Government's lack of capacity and determination to do the very things that it talks so consistently about-to consult with the industry, to examine the industry's position in the economy and to come to some sort of responsible consensus. Obviously it has refused to do that. As late as, I think, 24 November last year the Minister for Primary Industry again insisted that the Government would be pursuing this legislation and the imposition of these extraordinarily heavy charges at a time which was perhaps the most inappropriate.

The purpose of the Bill is to validate meat inspection charges from 1 January 1983 to 21 November 1983 due to a technical deficiency in the legislation since the beginning of the year. The Bill certainly should not be passed by this Parliament until the sort of investigation that I and the Opposition have referred to has been carried out. Fortunately the Government has established a proper inquiry into the cost problems of this most important industry but having done that why on earth it should pursue the legislation seems beyond understanding.

The whole matter arose in the first place because of the Government's determination in the 1983 Budget to impose very significantly increased charges for meat inspection. 'Significantly' is not nearly a strong enough term, because the charges that were imposed as a result of that Budget represented an increase of 200 per cent, an increase from $1.80 to $5.40 per head-an insufferable proposition. The original Commonwealth charge of $1.80, which had been in force, unaltered, since 1979, compared more or less favourably with the charges in the States of $1.50 in New South Wales, $2.08 in Victoria and as low as $1.06 in Queensland.

This sort of increase was an insufferable addition to the cost structure of an industry that had been finding times difficult indeed. It occurred at a time when the industry, like many other of Australia's rural industries, was recovering from the most severe drought in its history. An increase at such a time was impossible for the leaders of and participators in the great primary industry in general and in the meat industry in particular to understand. There seemed to be no justification for an industry, fighting its way through a drought, to be suddenly hit by a 200 per cent increase in one section of its cost structure.

People probably fail to recognise that for rural industry to recover from a drought of the severity of the 1982 drought, following as it did a pretty lean period in 1979, 1980 and 1981, takes a very significant time indeed, particularly in the livestock industry. The livestock industry needs a period not of weeks or months but of years to recover in terms of numbers and standard of stock and in its capacity to compete in the world market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some areas are still affected by drought.
—Exactly.

—Some people have forgotten this. As Senator Harradine says and Senator Crichton-Browne from Western Australia says, some areas of Australia are still very significantly affected by drought. Since they remind me of that, I should also say that some significant areas of primary producing land in Australia are almost totally devastated by flood. There is an irony in the fact that after literally years of drought, one should be ravaged by flood, which can be almost as devastating. So the period needed for recovery after the drought and the consequences of the drought, I suggest, make this legislation more inappropriate now than it could ever have been.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter that makes this a totally inappropriate time to consider even some increase in charges-if indeed there is to be any-is the fact that the industry is struggling and has struggled through a period of depressed prices. Competitively it finds itself in a very serious situation. It has taken this industry many years to recover to some real degree from the loss of market it suffered when the United Kingdom moved into the European Economic Community and as a result of that Community's attitudes. I believe that the sort of competition with which this great meat industry in Australia is confronted is worth remembering. It is a very significant competition with competitors who are helped immeasurably by their governments and their taxpayers. The meat industry in Australia stands on its own feet. It relies on its own efficiency and on its breeding capacities and standards to compete around the world. It is an industry which has virtually no support from the Australian community. Basically it does not seek that support, but it does seek a fair deal in areas such as cost structure, over which governments have a significant measure of control.

It is important to recognise that this industry, unaided in Australia and confronting on world markets all forms of competition, is an industry which does not have the sorts of benefits that are common to its major competitors. I believe, for instance, that we should remind ourselves of the circumstances of the European Economic Community, where there is a complete block-out of the mass of Australian products and where prices are bolstered by a very significant subsidised system, to the extent that subsidised surpluses are nowadays moving into the free markets of the world and making those markets very much more difficult places indeed. So our producers face enormous subsidising of competitors in the European Economic Community.

It is worth remembering that in the last couple of years New Zealand has subsidised its sheep meat industry by in excess of $500m. South America, a competitor of Australia in the beef and veal markets of the world, has preferential access to many parts of Europe and export rebates and long term cheap loans. These are some of the advantages of yet another competitor. On the Australian side of the coin, the Australian producer virtually starts about $40m behind scratch because that is his contribution to meat export inspection.

The meat industry in Australia represents something like $1.5 billion in export earning capacity, and something like $1.2 billion of that is referable to beef and veal alone. When talking of the problems which have confronted this industry and which have been significantly increased by the determination of the Government to press ahead with the proposition of a 200 per cent increase in charges it is worth remembering that the state of the industry is bringing about significant unemployment in a whole range of areas. In the abattoir areas around Australia many people have been laid off. Hundreds of workers have been laid off in meat works in Victoria, Tasmania, Western Australia, Queensland and New South Wales. Some of these meat works are closing down and some have closed down altogether. Others are in a skeleton staff situation.

I suppose it is worth recalling the measures that the Government has taken to help the steel workers in this country. That may well be a good thing; I am not saying that it is or is not. But clearly that same sort of responsibility and concern has not been exhibited towards rural workers in this country who in this case cover a very wide range of people, including people in the refrigeration and transport industries as well as people within the precincts of the abattoirs themselves. Hundreds and, indeed, thousands of people are involved, and many hundreds have already lost their jobs. Not only have those hundreds lost their jobs but also literally thousands of people are living in complete uncertainty and dismay just wondering whether this week or next week, or next month, their area of operation and work will be forced to close down because it has become non-competitive, basically as a result of the enormous and continuously increasing charges levelled at it.

I believe I have made clear the point that caused us to seek the adjournment of the debate on this legislation. It is virtually unbelievable that a government, having recognised, apparently, the need for consultation in this industry and the need to identify the penalty of charges being brought into the industry through the 200 per cent increase, having set up two proper committees, having given them clear instructions and guidelines for investigation and having asked them to report as a matter of priority by about the end of April, should then seek to pursue this legislation. The Government was tardy enough in taking those steps and for a significant period, to the end of November, was arrogantly insistent that it would not alter the charges and would be pressing for their implementation.

For all those well-based and sound reasons we have sought the adjournment of the debate so that when matters come to a head again and when the question of export charges is examined again by the Government it will at least be in receipt of a responsible examination by responsible committees and will be talking with some real knowledge of the industry with which it seeks to discuss and come to some responsible arrangement in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Scott, before he commenced his speech, said that this was an extraordinary performance. He then proceeded to display, as I expect the four or five Opposition speakers to follow him will display, either culpable ignorance or a piece of cheap and irresponsible political grandstanding designed to confuse and mislead the industry and public. Of course, there is nothing extraordinary about either culpable ignorance or cheap or irresponsible political grandstanding from members of the Opposition. The simple fact is that none of the comments he made had anything at all to do with this Bill and, therefore, provide no justification whatsoever for its deferral.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation imposing higher charges which became operative from 1 October last year has already been passed by the Senate and was not opposed by Senator Scott or anybody else. Whether this Bill is deferred or passed will make absolutely no difference to the current liability of any abattoir operator in Australia to pay the levy. I do not believe all members of the Opposition are so culpably ignorant that they do not know those facts. I am, therefore, forced to conclude that this exercise is nothing but a cheap and irresponsible piece of political grandstanding. Senator Scott's comments bear the same relationship to reality that the scurrilous, infamous and discredited allegations made by his Leader last October bore, although at least his present Leader, then his Deputy Leader, had the decency to make his scurrilous, discredited and infamous allegations before his own red-necked cheer squad and did not insult the national Parliament by bringing them before it.

All this Bill does is correct a technical defect, that is, a failure to prescribe abattoir premises, in a regulation which had been issued pursuant to the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Act, which regulation was issued on 1 January 1983 and remained in force until 21 November 1983. After 21 November 1983 the technical defect was corrected by the issue of a regulation without that technical defect. As a result of that technical defect having been corrected, I stress again, all the abattoirs are liable to pay the charges prescribed by the legislation passed last year and not opposed by Senator Scott or anybody else. The deferral or passage of this Bill will make absolutely no difference to the liability of any operator to pay the current charges.

On 1 October last year the charges were increased. In that interim period during which they were being applied under a technically defective regulation, that is, from 1 January to 30 September last year, the previous and lower rate of charges applied. I am advised that a total of $11m was collected. Again I am advised that those moneys, although not in the technical sense correctly collected, cannot be returned. Until 30 September last year there was no deliberate attempt by any abattoir operator not to pay the levy although I understand that because of insolvency some levies are still outstanding. On 1 October the charge, again collected under a technically defective regulation, was increased and between 1 October and 21 November, when the technical defect was corrected, some firms appear to have deliberately withheld in part or in full the payment of the levy.

Since 21 November last year some other firms, and probably the same firms, either have not paid the levy or have not paid it in full. The non-payment of the levy beyond 21 November was clearly illegal and action to recover will be taken and indeed is in progress. The position of those who either did not pay the full levy or did not pay the levy at all between 1 October and 21 November is less clear. I am informed that in aggregate in the period since 1 October approximately 40 per cent of firms operating abattoirs are in some degree of arrears of payment. The legal processes for the recovery of those charges are being pursued and letters of demand will shortly be sent to those people in arrears.

It is simply irresponsible to confuse the facts of this admittedly somewhat complex issue by dragging in an issue, as Senator Scott has done, which has absolutely nothing to do with the substance of this Bill. I emphasise that all that the Bill seeks to do is to correct a technical defect in a regulation issued by the former National Party Minister for Primary Industry. The purpose of the Bill is to correct the errors and negligence of the former National Party Minister, and it has nothing to do with the level of charges currently being applied for export inspection services or the legal obligation of abattoir operators to pay those charges.

If the validation Bill is not passed-and Senator Scott's motion seeks to defer further consideration until after 1 May-I have been advised that those operators who paid their full levy between 1 October and 21 November cannot recover those moneys that they have paid. Those who have either not paid at all or not paid in full between 1 October and 21 November may not be-I stress 'may not' be, because opinion seems to be divided on this matter-legally obliged to pay the levy until this validation Bill is passed.

What Senator Scott proposes to do-and I presume that the other Liberal Party and/or National Party speakers who follow him will propose to do the same thing- is to continue to leave in doubt the obligation to pay by those who have either not paid in full or not paid at all between 1 October and 21 November 1983. Those firms which have done the right thing and paid are finished with, regardless of whether this validation Bill is passed. Those who have not paid may not be legally obliged to pay unless and until the Bill is passed. The proposition that Senator Scott is asking the Senate to accept is that those who have met their obligations under the law are finished; those who have not met their obligations under the law will be allowed, at least for the time being, to escape and avoid those obligations.

I do not intend to comment on all the totally extraneous and irrelevant material about the level of charges to which Senator Scott has referred, for the simple and totally adequate reason that none of those comments has anything whatsoever to do with this Bill, which an irresponsible and mischievous Opposition seeks to defer. All that the Opposition proposal will achieve is the creation of more rich lawyers, as the Government proceeds to endeavour to recover obligations due from some meat processors, abattoir operators, without certain legislative backing to collect those arrears of payments.

Senator Scott referred to the study recently announced by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, by the Interim Inspection Policy Council, a body which, I understand, includes representatives of all those who pay for inspection services, not just meat inspection services but the unions involved in meat inspection services, the State and Federal Governments and consumers, and which is due to report by April. That study will not deal with the subject matter of the Bill. Any changes which may be made as a result of its conclusions and recommendations will be applicable to the future only, and not to the past. All that this Bill seeks to do is to correct a technical defect in a regulation issued by the previous National Party Minister for Primary Industry on 1 January 1983. It has absolutely nothing to do with the level of meat inspection charges.

There is no valid reason whatsoever why the Bill should not be passed without delay. The invalid reason why it will not be passed without delay is that, taking a charitable view, those members of the Opposition who vote for Senator Scott's motion are culpably ignorant. The less charitable and, I suspect, more accurate view is, as I have said, that they are engaged in a cheap and irresponsible piece of political grandstanding deliberately designed to confuse and mislead the industry and the public, an incidental effect of which will be to leave the Commonwealth in an uncertain legal position in future attempts to recover arrears of payments due and probably to create a number of other rich lawyers. No honourable senator who is informed on this matter-and after my comments there is absolutely no excuse for senators being ill-informed or not being aware of the facts-and no senator who has any sense of responsibility, any sense of the duties of this House of the Australian Parliament will support Senator Scott's motion. I urge honourable senators not to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to Senator Walsh for, as usual, being able to provide me with such good advice. It is also very refreshing to find that he can come back into this Parliament for his first contribution in 1984 in exactly the same tenor as he would have left it in 1983, 1982, 1981 and so on. Still, I am used to his degree of flattery and complimentary offerings, so I do not really mind saying that I disagree with him . I think it is quite reasonable that honourable senators should have the opportunity not to just say 'Yes sir, no sir, three bags full sir', because I disagree with him and I want to make that clear.
—He misled the Parliament on the last day.

—I do not care whether he misled the Parliament on the last day or today. I just disagree with what he is putting and the premise on which he is putting it. I am not here to mislead the meat industry in all its forms in Australia. I am not here to mislead the growers, the unions, the processors, the exporters or all the other carriers, packers, box-makers and anyone else mixed up with this. What I am trying to do is to see that the industry at large is recognised for what it is and that we do our best to ensure that it survives and strengthens.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not get any joy out of seeing the actions of any government reducing the amount of work that is available. I do not want to see lay-offs in jobs. I do not want to see costings that will just eliminate the industry piece by piece. I do not want to see the present 20 per cent reduction that is anticipated in 1984 grow to a 30 per cent reduction in 1985. I do not want to be guilty of hypocritically talking here about booms in the rural industry. Where are these booms in the rural industry that everybody has been chanting about for months? Do honourable senators think they are in the sugar industry? Do they think they are in the vegetable industry, the grape industry or the dairy industry? Has a boom shown up in the meat industry? It is the meat industry we are currently talking about. No, such a boom certainly has not shown up there. It is my belief that the Government made a simple mistake of accepting advice from one of its advisory groups which said: 'She'll be right; the industry can stand it'.

The main purpose of my contesting the continuing debate on this Bill today is at least to give the Government an opportunity just to look at the stupidity that goes on in this area. It is absolutely ridiculous for us to continue while we are imperilling the industry day by day. The Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr Kerin) fully understands what is going on. It would have been unthinkable for him to have organised these committees of inquiry and given them his wholehearted support if he really felt that what we were doing was the ideal thing. Of course it is not the ideal thing. The terms of the inquiry and the information that has been put out already say it all. The decision to promote these uneconomic fees was based on fallacies. I still believe that the Government is able to take the necessary actions now. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) so adequately covered the matter last week when he promised us mistakes. This is one of the mistakes that he promised us. I quite understand that the people who are making these decisions at various levels are short of information and that accordingly it is likely that they will make mistakes in areas where they lack practical knowledge and contact with people at large. I believe that the information that they are working on should be better than it is. I think there should be more understanding.

In my State the meat industry is in a lot of trouble. I would like to see a little more consideration given as to how we are going to assist it to build up. It is one of the things that we in Tasmania can do very well. If we had a little more help from some of our bureaucrats and senatorial colleagues we might be able to achieve something. If people from my State come here trying to validate the nonsense that the Government is producing, I will be very sorry for them when they get home and face their growers. I support the growers, the industry and the unions. I do not want us to go through these continuing rounds of enormous union stand-downs. I do not want us to eliminate the standard of inspection that we have but I want the Government to understand that before we validate these things that it arranged last year we are giving it the chance to have another look at what it has done.

Let us look at this inquiry. I believe it will be a good inquiry. I think that the Minister has grappled with the question very well. I certainly commend the fact that we are to have a proper look at it to see just what the economics of it are and what the results will be. I want to ensure that we get an opportunity to cover the position as widely as we can. I have made a little space in the Tasmanian newspapers and on the air this week to urge everybody in the industry to give evidence to the inquiry. I do the same Australia-wide. I hope that everybody who has any association with the meat industry in Australia will make a submission. While we have this feeling that we are suffering from a rural boom and that the millionaires in the bush have to be brought to heel, these sorts of things get through. If we study the realities we see that the average Australian farmer earns $11,400 a year. What is the average weekly income now? It is $350- odd a week. I believe I saw that figure in the newspaper this week. Let us compare that figure with the average annual income of $11,400 for members of the entire farming population of Australia.

How can we skin this louse any more if we try to chase these figures any higher ? I again raise the question of the pig inspections. The cost to the pig producers of Australia is greater than the cost to the total export industry. It just cannot last. I have also been talking to the people who export fish, dairy products, vegetables and honey. They are all in the same boat. I cannot get the Government to understand that, according to the information that I got from the Parliament Library in the last few days, in New Zealand almost the total cost of export inspection schemes is met by the Government. In Canada, as in New Zealand , the Government is responsible for the cost of almost all export inspection charges. Details of inspection scheme costs in the United States of America were procurable only in relation to meat. Unlike the current situation in Australia where the Federal Government has adopted a policy of recovering 50 per cent of the cost of export meat inspection, meat in the United States of America is inspected by Federal inspectors at no cost to either the farmer or the exporter. That alone puts a cost of $40m against the producers in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the razor gang?

—I know that Senator Tate does not give a damn for the meat producers in Australia, but I do. If he wants to squawk about how much he hates them he is welcome to follow me in this debate. In the meantime, I am trying to protect the unionists as well as the producers. I want to be able to say that I have at least done my best to obscure these ridiculous charges and to preserve the industry.
—You are a hypocrite, an absolute hypocrite.

—I believe that these things are part of our entire overall social cost. We have a system in Australia which provides considerable benefits to certain sections of the community. Where considerable benefits are provided to certain sections it is done so at the expense of others.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I heard Senator Tate call Senator Archer a hypocrite. That is an unparliamentary expression and I ask that Senator Tate be asked to withdraw it.
—Senator Tate will withdraw the remark.
—Mr Deputy President, in deference to the Chair I will withdraw that remark.

—Thank you. If we really feel that we need to have a meat industry, we will find, as with other primary industries that it is necessary for us to regard ourselves as an international exporting country. If we are to meet the other exporters of the world on the world markets we have to do so on a reasonably comparable basis. We as Australians have set ourselves an urban standard of living which is the envy of everybody else in the world. We have achieved that at the expense of the rural community in matters such as this. The countries that I mentioned-Canada, New Zealand and the United States of America- also have decided that a high standard of living for their population, mainly their urban population, is desirable. They have also decided that as a result of the cost that this places on their primary producers in world markets they at least will contribute something towards the costs that they create. They pay the export inspection charges as a cost against the community as a whole. I have always recommended that that should be done, and I still do. I believe that it is a quite reasonable cost and that it is obviously acceptable by international trading standards. I think that the results of what happens in other places and the effect on our competitiveness should be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: Are these costs and standards reasonable? The standards are, yes. I am not in any doubt that we have the highest and best standards in the world. As to the costs, I am quite sure that the inquiry that the Minister has now set up will produce a lot of very interesting figures and comparable costs to show that the costs are ridiculous. In the latter stages of the parliamentary session last year I received from the Minister the breakdown on how the various parts of the export inspection service are put together. I have been able to circulate that to various sections of the exporting community. I have already received a considerable amount of information. The people who are paying these costs at present-the people who are participating in the service-would very much like to have an opportunity to discuss what is necessary, what responsibility is to be given and taken and how it would best be carried out. To the best of my knowledge this has not been done up until now. I have discussed this matter in Estimates committees at various times. Regrettably, it does not seem as if there is any great intention to let the people who are involved in the system from the practical point of view really to have any worthwhile input into it. I think that in itself would involve a lot of change.

If we were able to rearrange this question of responsibility and cost I believe that the costs would be reduced enormously. This would show the necessity of this legislation to validate these ridiculous and stupid costs. It should not be necessary to have to validate these ridiculous costs. I certainly will never agree that these costs are reasonable; they should be absorbed. I do not want to see any of the workers in the industry having to look for other jobs when there are jobs available. This is an industry that we should be extending and expanding. Let us get evidence from this inquiry before we close the door on export inspections.

I was somewhat surprised to hear the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, who spoke before me in this debate, saying that the payers were finished; if they had paid they were done. The non-payers might be off the hook. I am a great believer in the generous heart of Senator Walsh on matters such as this. I am sure that if he found somebody was being disadvantaged he would see that he paid back the amount that may have been held not to have been payable. I am not really in any doubt that he will do that. I am not in any doubt that it could not be done if he was so worried about it.

I think this whole question demonstrates a fairly heavy-handed bureaucratic bungle. We are now going through the justification process which is normal when mistakes have been made. I find it very refreshing to have the Prime Minister saying: 'You knew I would make mistakes; I promised you mistakes'. I think we accept that. I would now like to see him following that up by saying: 'This inspection charge is a classic case. We will fix it'.

I really do not understand why it is seen as necessary, in spite of what Senator Walsh has said, to bring this debate on now before the hearings are concluded and the decisions are taken. Clearly, an enormous mistake has been made. We need to clear it up as best we can. Once this validation legislation is in place and the people who have made this mistake have covered it up, the chances of getting it openly admitted and discussed and having rectifying legislation brought through are not very good. It is in the interests of the public at large and, in this case, the meat producers in particular, that there should be a delay until we are able to see how big this classic error is. The Government can then advise, in the debating stages on the Live-stock Slaughter ( Export Inspection Charge) Validation Bill, what it intends to do about it. I really believe that that is the best thing that we can hope to do. I make no apologies at all for being prepared to endeavour to keep the matter before the Government until the mistakes are put right.

I was interested to hear Senator Walsh mention that some of the processors had not paid because they have solvency problems. He would not need to be all that smart to work out the reason that they have solvency problems. If he really went into it he would find that the actual costs we are now imposing, coupled with the natural problems of years of drought, run down in maintenance, falling stock numbers and greater competition from overseas people who are better treated on the world market than our processors, are the reasons for insolvency. But apparently somewhere along the line that has not quite got through to him.

We are still confronted by this profitability question, this boom syndrome. We still see articles about it in the Press. Obviously the meat inspection charges were built around this high profitability and the fact that the growers and the processors could stand it. The rural sector has in no way got back to a buoyant, competitive and profitable situation. In certain sectors some degree of improvement enabled some of the backlag to be taken up. I know very few farmers, even those who are fairly successful in the grain business, who are able to come back and say that they are making a profit. In most cases they were able to say that they had reduced some of their losses. In many cases it resulted in them having to spend a lot of money trying to catch up with some of their necessary maintenance or restocking in some areas. That does not seem to have got through to the Minister. It concerns me that this apparent blockage is still before us.

I was somewhat surprised to see again in the Press this week that the wheatgrowers, who were carrying this fallacy, are still reported as having had a huge, profitable year. There may be areas where this has happened. But overall, losses have already resulted from weather damage. The Almighty, who provided the grain, took a lot of it back with the rain. He may now well follow that up with what I see the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has referred to as 50,000 mice to the hectare. The Government needs also to take into account that our overseas export markets are not very good at present, even though in the last week or two we found that the meat industry has a new champion who goes to Japan, Korea and other places and assures us that all is well. History shows that Japan bought 101,000 tonnes of beef from Australia in 1979 and 85,000 tonnes in 1982. There was a further decline of about 17 per cent in 1983 and there is an anticipated decline of 17 per cent in 1984. The only problem about this is that nobody has yet said from where the new markets will come to replace that decline. There is also the question of freight. Freight rates are creating a real crisis for our export industry. I do not think that it is reasonable to allow Australian freight rates to continue to rise at a time when we are increasing the costs which high freight rates impose. That is really what is happening now. The higher the costs which keep the freight rates up, the less the return for the producer and the processor.

These figures are interesting: In 1976 there were 1,700 inspectors and the kill totalled 11 million cattle and 32 million sheep. By 1983 the kill would have closed at about 6.3 million, as against 11 million cattle and 26 million, as against 32 million, sheep. Only the number of inspectors rose substantially. Although the numbers of slaughtered stock were down by 40 per cent the number of inspectors had increased by 30 per cent, from 1,700 to 2,200. I find it quite extraordinary that we can have a system under which this is possible.

With all the compliments that Senator Walsh was able to extend to us for having a desire to try to do something to keep the plight of the meat industry before the Parliament, in spite of the fact that he believes it is not right that we should do so and in spite of the fact that the figures on which the costs were raised have been shown to be demonstrably, totally wrong, I still have an interest in seeing that this major industry in Australia is protected. I thing it is better to advance its interests than to damage them. I only hope that honourable senators will take the same view. I urge the Government to get on with the inquiry that it has now set up and to bring the report to the Parliament as soon as possible, together with the plans that it has for rectifying the gross and unfortunate mistakes that the last legislative procedures produced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to urge the Senate today to consider and deliberate as much as it wishes and then to vote upon the Live-stock Slaughter ( Export Inspection Charge) Validation Bill. I do regret my outburst in the course of Senator's Archer's remarks, which I did withdraw, but I did feel he was putting forward a species of rural socialism which lay ill at ease with many other of his political stances. He has put forward in this chamber, as a model for Australian taxpayers to follow, a situation in which Australian taxpayers should do--
—I raise a point of order. This is absolute nonsense. I did nothing of the sort. I just do not go along with this sort of rubbish.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As the Deputy President has ruled, there is no point of order. The honourable senator has put forward, as a possible model for Australia to follow, a system which is apparently the practice in some other primary export producing countries whereby their taxpayers underwrite their export inspection services 100 per cent. That is what the honourable senator said. I find that lays very ill at ease with his attitude, for example, to the Medicare scheme, under which we asked the Australian taxpayers to underwrite 100 per cent by way of a one per cent levy the health, medical and hospital care costs of ordinary Australians. I say that the community underwriting of health care is at least as important as the export of cattle.
—What are we talking about?

—I am talking about inconsistency in political stances, which was brought into this chamber. The Bill has been completely misunderstood by the Opposition. All we are seeking to do is to validate the collection of meat inspection fees levied from 1 January 1983 to 21 November 1983. Since late November the increased levy has been the subject of valid regulation. This has not raised protests within this chamber. It has not been the subject, for example, of a disallowance motion. It is, in fact, in operation. So we are merely talking about a Bill to validate the imposition of a levy from 1 January to 20 November last year. Up to 1 October last year that relates to the old levy , the levy imposed by Senator Archer's Party when in government.
—We know that.

—If the honourable senator knows that he ought to be supporting this Bill, because this Bill merely seeks to rectify a defect in the administration and the executive action of the previous Government in failing to validly construct a regulation to impose that old levy, which was of its making, up to 1 October 1983. We are merely trying to rectify what was so poorly undertaken by the previous Government. We are seeking to collect the levy imposed by the previous Government up to 1 October. Insofar as the increase of the levy applies from 1 October, yes there is a six-week period when this Bill, if passed, would validate the collection of the increased meat inspection levy.

SPEECH.PARA: I am afraid the total confusion in the minds of the Opposition-this is very apparent in the contribution of Senator Scott, whom I greatly admire-means that what the Opposition is doing is encouraging a confusion which I believe leads to many facilities using meat inspection services failing over the last few months to make their proper contribution as required now by law. It is a fact that many of these places and abattoirs have not made the payments as required by law. I think that they have been under a misapprehension that those payments required over the last several months would truly be required only if this Bill were passed. That is not the case. Those requirements are validly in place. But in saying that I also point out that it would be quite wrong to say that the Government is not aware of the situation within the meat export industry. As we all know, that industry has passed through an extremely traumatic and long, drawn-out period, with the drought exacerbating the situation.

The meat inspection levy-I notice Senator Archer is very interested in this as a noted beef producer himself-is in fact one of several government levies that are imposed on the industry. We cannot simply focus on the meat inspection levy as the cause-if there is said to be a cause-of the decline of the industry. Clearly the meat inspection levy is but one part of a series of government levies and one part of the overall costs of the industry which, as I said, was very markedly affected by the drought. The improvement of conditions led to the withholding of much stock. Some people would see that as a bit of a paradox, but it is quite clear why that would be the case. With the breaking of the drought and the improvement in pastures much stock was withheld and there is still not a sufficient throughput through the abattoirs to allow them to operate efficiently .

One can point to several other charges which are imposed on that industry. I think I recall-I have not been able to put my hand on it this morning-a catalogue of such charges. There is the Australian Meat Research Committee charge, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation research component, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation component charge for administration of meat promotion and the brucellosis, tuberculosis eradication campaign. In regard to sheep meat there is the market development fund for sheep and lambs. I do recall that last year the report of the Australian Meat Research Committee came into this chamber. It was disclosed by that authority that a much higher levy would have to be imposed in relation to its program of meat research just to produce sufficient revenue to maintain a 25 per cent reduced program due to the lower throughput of cattle through the abattoirs.

We are confronted by a situation where many charges are imposed by government and by industry on itself. I have instanced the Australian Meat Research Committee as being such a body. There are many instances of charges which enter into the costs of the meat industry.

The employment impact, therefore, of the increase in the meat inspection levy alone is not as considerable or as marked as is made out by the Opposition. I concede that it is a component. Of course, any increase in any item of cost must bear upon the overall viability of a particular enterprise. But the decline in the work force in the abattoir meat export industry cannot be laid at the feet of the increase in this levy which, as I say, operates absolutely validly and without question only from 21 November and has been sought to be applied only from 1 October 1983. The decline was very considerable over a period of years until that time. For example, available statistics indicate that in the period from 1976-77 to 1981-82-that is, a five year period-employment in the abattoir and meat processing industry in Australia dropped from 48,815 to 33,430, a decrease of 32 per cent. There had already been a 32 per cent decline in employment over that five-year period, the period when the former Government was in office and operating the meat inspection levy at its current rate. The rate of decrease was particularly pronounced in the period 1979-80 to 1981-82, when employment dropped by nearly 10,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you tell your Caucus this?
