—During that time a total of 32 export works were closed permanently. In other words, during the period when the previous Government was in office, imposing its levy, there was a decline.
—We had a drought.

—I am trying to make the very point that many factors were operating to bring about the decline in employment and the rationalisation within the industry over that five-year or six-year year period. The Opposition certainly cannot lay the decline in the industry at the feet of the proposed increase in the levy. We ought to be asking in this debate whether this Bill ought to pass through the Senate's deliberative processes today. I am indicating that this Bill applies to the previous Government's levy until 1 October and merely validates it and rectifies a defect in the way in which it drew up the regulations. Therefore, I cannot see how any honourable senator on the other side of the chamber can say that that is an improper procedure for the Senate to undertake today.

SPEECH.PARA: What we do today will make no impact whatsoever on the levying of the increased meat inspection charge from 21 November. So I do not see that there is any significance in what we do today in relation to that levy. There may be some significance in what we do in relation to the six-week period from 1 October to 21 November. It is true that if we pass this legislation today it will be very clear that the levying of that increased charge over the six-week period is without any doubt a valid government operation, and therefore not subject to various court challenges which are very confusing. As I say, I believe that many operators of abattoirs and meat producers, tend to get confused with the periods on either side of the six-week period. This therefore leads to their engaging, perhaps unwittingly, in an illegal withholding of the correct payment of the levy. At the time when some of us were preparing to debate this matter late last year, I wanted to argue that there was a clear case for further consultation by the Government with the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, with the Caucus.

—With the industry. It is correct that I raised the matter within the Caucus. I thought that further consultation within the industry and with bodies which are involved ought to be undertaken. I am pleased to see that the Government has responded by setting up the Interim Inspection Policy Council. The Council has been given a crucial role in developing and implementing policies relating to the inspection of primary produce in general. Absolute priority is to be given to the range of questions dealing with the meat inspection levy. The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, in his address at the setting up of the Inspection Policy Council on 14 February this year, made it clear that he would ask the Chairman to arrange for Council, as a matter of priority, to carry out a re-examination of the financial and economic aspects of the impact of inspection costs on the meat industry and to report by the end of April.

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime, the Government believes that its policy of asking the taxpayers of Australia to underwrite-this is the way that it should be put-the meat inspection service to the tune of 50 per cent ought to be allowed to operate. We are not saying that in light of that particular range of consultations that is not open to some modification. But the Senate is being asked to agree that it is reasonable that the Australian taxpayer should underwrite the meat inspection service to the tune of 50 per cent of its costs as presently assessed. There are questions of whether the assessment of costs is correct and whether the figure of 50 per cent is correct. No doubt these matters will be the subject of report by the Inspection Policy Council. But I do not think it is reasonable to ask the Australian taxpayer to continue underwriting the meat inspection service to the tune of say, 70 per cent, 75 per cent or 80 per cent. We have made a judgment that it should be 50 per cent and we put to the Senate that that ought to be the case for the six-week period from 1 October to 21 November.

Consultations by the Inspection Policy Council are being undertaken. As Senator Archer said, it is essential that meat producers and abattoir operators make their views known as quickly and as comprehensively as possible. I am sure that under the chairmanship of Mr Meynink, who is also Chairman of the Livestock and Meat Authority of Queensland, the Interim Inspection Policy Council will fairly assess the situation. I believe, however, that it is sufficient in the debate today to point out the very small impact of this legislation and in regard to the further questions, await the report of the Inspection Policy Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate today because I am very concerned about the Australian Labor Party's attitude to the people of rural Australia. The motion that the Senate is debating at the moment calls for the inspection levy to be held at the present level until the Interim Inspection Policy Council, which the Government has set up, brings down its findings in approximately one month's time. I cannot for the life of me see why the Government cannot wait for one month before acting on the findings which are brought down. I am sure that the Senate will respond to the Government and help it in any way that it likes. But at the moment the Senate is saying: 'You have set up an inquiry; for goodness sake wait until the inquiry brings down its results, because it it pointless to set up an inquiry and then not listen to it' . I want to discuss some of the other repercussions if the $1.80 levy is increased to $5.40. In my home State of Queensland at the moment the export abattoirs are paying $5.40 for the cost of inspection, whether the beast is to be exported or whether it is for home consumption.
—In export registered abattoirs.

—Yes, in export registered abattoirs. Of course, people are not sending beef to be killed in export abattoirs. They are sending it to non-export licensed abattoirs. Of course, the non-export licensed abattoirs have a full book; the export licensed abattoirs are going broke at a fast rate. Of course the export licensed abattoirs need the local kill and the export kill to be viable. I do not think the Government has considered that. A lot of the export abattoirs are caught in a cleft stick, not knowing which way to go. Some have surrendered their licences, some have given up.

SPEECH.PARA: I instance the position in the little town of Kilcoy, just 60 or 70 miles out of Brisbane. The abattoir there has a $196,000 a year meat inspection levy because it has an export licence. However, half the beef that is killed is for the local market. Of course these people cannot make a profit and are wondering what they should do. I will not mention the situation in the pig industry, as Senator Archer has done. Since this Bill was introduced a number of abattoirs have given it away. I see that Senator Tate has left the chamber, but I can tell him that in his home State of Tasmania S. P. Holman and Sons Pty Ltd has gone broke and the Longford Meat Co. and Richardson's Meat Industries Ltd have closed . In Victoria Meat Pak (Victoria) Pty Ltd has shut, as has J. H. Ralph and Sons Pty Ltd. Of course, the consequences for employment are horrendous. It is no time at all to be putting up charges. In the last two years in Australia 35 abattoirs have closed. In two years 6,000 jobs in the meat industry have been lost. I put it to honourable senators on the Government side that a lot of these people support them. However, the Government is not supporting these people by allowing an increase in levy from $1.80 to $5.40. Of course, the Government's action will increase unemployment in abattoirs and meat works.

The meat export industry is worth $1 billion to Australia. It was Australia's leading rural export earner. Now it ranks sixth in rural export earnings. Admittedly the drought had some effect. Australia just cannot compete with the highly subsidised industries overseas. No country Australia competes with charges any sort of inspection levy. Canada, America and New Zealand do not charge a meat inspection levy. In fact New Zealand is heavily subsidised, to the tune of $500m. I note that Senator Tate is trying to bring in a red herring by saying we are advocating socialism. If Australia wants a meat industry that provides 40,000 jobs and earns $1 billion in export earnings it has to offset some of the costs against those benefits.

I will talk a little further about the competition that Australia faces from a lot of other countries. Just three or four months before Christmas Egypt put out an order and tenders were called. Australia put in a tender. However, Australia lost the tender by 20c a kilo to the heavily subsidised European Economic Community country, Ireland. Not only did Australia lose by 20c a kilo but the EEC picked up the account and carried it for 90 days. We cannot compete against the sorts of benefits that other countries are offering. The benfits have to be balanced out overall. The benefits have to be balanced and offset against the disadvantage of the Government's having to carry some of the weight. Honourable senators must realise that an industry which employs 40,000 people needs some sort of protection.

Another point I raise in the debate today is the claim that the industry is not efficient. I refer to the headline in the Country Life 'Pay cheque for $400,000 but no work'. That article shows that 20 Northern Territory meat inspectors were under suspension. Of course, it is the meat industry-the grazier-which has to pick up the tab for the inefficiencies of the Government's meat inspection service. I bring to the attention of the Senate a number of other points. For example, the Hawke Government continues to have a complete disregard for rural Australia. That is only one example of its disregard.

I will mention a few more. I will tell the people of Australia what the Federal Government has done to the rural industries in only one year. The Government has reduced the general depreciation allowance; removed the tax incentive from the income equalisation deposits scheme; imposed a 2c a litre increase on the excise on aviation fuel; abolished the special depreciation allowance for petrol storage; abolished the automatic in and out opting provisions for tax averaging schemes; cancelled the bicentennial water resources program; decreased at a cost of $10m in 1983-84 the subsidy payable under the petroleum product freight subsidy scheme; increased the interest payments on Telecom Australia and Australia Post resulting in higher telephone and postal charges. The Government intends to increase massively meat export inspection charges, which is the matter we are discussing today. I hope the Government does not do that today. I hope that common sense prevails in the Senate. The Government has provided only $20m for wool promotion although $28m was promised during the election. It has provided only $1m towards national soil conservation and has placed an excise tax on fortified wine despite the categoric election promise that there would be no sales tax on wine. The Government has increased the excise on manufactured tobacco and further cut back petroleum product freight subsidies. I could go on and on.

I ask how this squares with the Prime Minister's unqualified commitment to maintaining the viability of Australia's great rural sector and provisional infrastructure. That does not square at all. The people of rural Australia have been asked to carry too much of the cost recovery burden of this nation. I ask the Senate to let common sense prevail when voting on this motion and to wait for the findings of the Government's Inspection Policy Council. I am sure the Government and all honourable senators will then realise that the industry just cannot increase its cost. Some exporters are narrowly winning contracts by .5c a kilo. The exporters cannot carry this extra levy. The abattoirs cannot carry it and still be competitive. It will go back to the farmer and grazier. They are on the end of the line. As other honourable senators have said, farmers' and graziers' incomes are not even level with the average income of Australians. Their investments on their properties are returning one per cent or two per cent .

I think it is too much for this Government to expect the farmers and graziers of this nation to carry an industry which provides so much employment and so many export dollars and which is of such benefit to Australia. Surely to goodness the Government must realise that it was elected on a promise to provide 500,000 jobs. If the Government increases this levy it will knock off probably 10,000 or 12,000 jobs of abattoir meat works, truck drivers and so on down to the carton makers and the waterside workers. These people are Government supporters; they are the people who are supposed to vote for the Government. Has not the Government any thought for them because they are the people it will hurt . Farmers and graziers realise that the Government does not give a damn for them but surely it can stand up and support its own people. I urge the Senate to support the motion to defer resumption of the debate and wait until the Council' s findings come down. I think that we may see some common sense in the situation .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated that the Australian Democrats will be supporting Senator Scott's motion to defer resumption of the debate until May. However, I must say that after hearing Senator Boswell's speech I am confused about precisely why the Opposition has moved the motion. Although nobody seems to be at all interested I think it may be well for me to try to spell out where precisely the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Validation Bill 1983 came from and to which set of fees it refers. It does not refer to the current charges. It does not refer to the Bills which were passed by this chamber on 14 September last year. Contrary to the claim made by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, they were not passed unanimously. The National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party all voted to increase the charges. Senator Boswell does not realise that he voted for the increase last year. In fact in this place he voted not only to increase the charges to $5.40 but also last year to increase them to $10.80. We are talking about charges made under a regulation which came into force in 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give some history on this matter because I believe it is important that we know precisely what it is we are talking about. It might be worth while for some honourable senators who thought that they were talking about an export levy to listen. Essentially the legislation that caused the problems was the Export Control Act 1982 which went through both Houses in June 1982. Prior to that date the ability of a person to inspect export beef relied on a range of quarantine and other Acts. The essential Act which was used in most cases, particularly if the matter were taken to court, was the Customs Act 1901. At that time there was a fair amount of discussion in the Government and elsewhere-it was the Liberal- National Country Party Government-as to what precisely would need to be done. It was felt that the Customs Act of 1901 did not give sufficient legislative power for what had been a growing area of meat inspection in particular.

The matter gained a great deal of impetus from the meat inspection scandal over which Mr Nixon, a National Party Minister at the time, presided. There were a great deal of discussions and committees of inquiry into the matter out of which came a package of 19 Bills. The Export Control Act of 1982 as it is now had attached to it a whole series of regulations. Of particular concern was the definition of 'premises' in the live-stock meat inspection legislation which previously referred to premises that were registered under the Export Control Bill. Those registered premises were included in the definition of the Live- stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Act 1979 which was the first time, of course, that the charges had been levied. For the first time a National Party Minister placed charges on exporting. I think it is well to remember-Senator Boswell obviously is not strong on history-that it was the National Party that presided over export charges when they were first introduced .

Unfortunately the definition of an abattoir was placed in the export control regulations and the prescribed premises were defined as those which were used for the carrying on of operations in connection with the slaughtering and dressing of animals from meat intended for export. There was an oversight in the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Act regarding this definition. It was not included under regulations made under that Act. Obviously advice had come from the Attorney-General's Department late last year that this definition may render invalid the collection of the charges made under the orginal Act when it came into force on 1 January 1983. The Government, whether or not through an excess of caution-we are not yet aware because no case has been made relating to this matter-brought in a validation Bill last year. At that time the Liberal and National parties had probably had quite enough of being hit about the head by the rural industry and decided that they had to do something. The reason for that is a point that Senator Boswell did not mention and that is the occurrence that took place in this chamber on 14 September last year. I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, moved a motion to limit the charges on meat export from the prime adult carcass which is taken as the reference. There are quite a large number of export charges in relation to a whole range of different meats but we generally take the prime adult carcass as the reference point. At that stage the charge was $1.80. The Government moved to make the maximum charge $10.80. However the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), in his second reading speech, said that the Government would not be seeking to extend the charge in the next financial year beyond $5.40 which is the figure that Senator Boswell talked about. I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, moved an amendment that we ought to limit the amount to $5.40 and I explained my reason for choosing that figure. I knew that the Liberal-National parties for some reason best known to themselves decided to pass whatever Bill the Government brought in and so I thought that if I moved an amendment which did not have, on the Government's say-so, financial implications for that financial year, I would get the support of the Liberal and National parties. On that basis I negotiated with the Minister for Primary Industry and although he was extremely reluctant to have any discussions on the matter and showed his concern about my seeking to move such an amendment, nevertheless he felt that there was nothing he could do about it. That was a relatively reasonable political stance. If he were not going to get the $10.80 levy but he would get the $5.40 which he wanted to collect, politically he would probably have to settle for that. But the unfortunate situation was the Senator Scott, speaking for the Liberal and National parties in this place, indicated that he would not support my amendment. Immediately that indication was given Senator Walsh, on behalf of the Government, indicated-it is in Hansard-that he was pleased with the Opposition's stance on the matter because if the charges had to be increased beyond $5.40 the Government would be able to do it this financial year which was precisely the reason why the Australian Democrats moved their amendment. It made sure that the Government did not go beyond that figure. That is the history of the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Validation Bill 1983.

The Bill is a National Party regulation which the National Party now seeks to defer. The reason that the Australian Democrats are supporting that deferral is that we will support anything at this time that keeps this matter at the forefront of political debate in this country. Unlike the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Labor Party, we believe that the way to collect export inspection charges is not to look at government costs and then charge 50 per cent, 60 per cent, 80 per cent or whatever arbitrary percentage happens to pop into one's mind, but rather to look at the capacity of the industry to pay.

Some extraordinary statements have been made in this chamber. I refer to one made by Senator Tate. He was talking about the throughput of abattoirs being down as a reason we should pass this Bill. I am not quite sure of the logic of that, but if one looks at the nation one finds that throughput is down. Senator Tate said that we could not attribute that totally or in any way to the charges. That is fair enough. But what we can attribute it to is the drought and to two of its consequences. One is that the total national herd has been cut enormously . Secondly, if a producer wishes to restock, he has to retain his stock to rebuild. Therefore, not as much stock is available after a drought for those two reasons. There is nothing particularly esoteric about that. I imagine that anybody who had any reasonable knowledge of what goes on in relation to animals would be able to work that out for himself. Yet Senator Tate adduced that as a reason we should pass the Bills.

Senator Tate then said that the decline in the profitability of the meat industry had been operating for a number of years. That is fair enough. It has been operating for a number of years. But let us not look at the last couple of years; let us look only at the period from mid-November last year onwards. Let us take that as our cut-off point. The reason I take that period is that the export charges, although valid for a month prior to that, would not have been collected for at least six weeks in the normal course of events. So the financial crunch would not come until six weeks after the original application date. I am not even going back to the day on which the extra charges came into force. I am going back to the day on which the charges would have to be paid by the abattoir.

Let us look at abattoirs around Australia. I will not give the names of the abattoirs. I have them here, but I have been asked to keep them confidential. There are obviously business reasons for that. I will simply name the States in which the abattoirs are. In Queensland, an abattoir suffered a 50 per cent drop in kill, leaving seven people unemployed. Traditional customers, as Senator Boswell said, have gone over to non-export works. In Western Australia, an abattoir relinquished export registration to the value of $3m. Three people there are now unemployed. It is now a non-export abattoir. In Victoria, the increased charges have made abattoirs completely non-competitive. In one abattoir, one hundred and thirty five people are out of work. In an abattoir in Tasmania 12 people are out of work. The abattoir is becoming non-competitive. In Victoria, an abattoir which is now non-competitive has closed down the entire cattle chain, putting 70 people out of work. In Tasmania the situation in another abattoir has put 30 people out of work. In Victoria another abattoir has laid off 50 people and newly repaired plant which was readied for operation in mid-September has not been commissioned, meaning that the three hundred people who would have had jobs there now do not. In Victoria, at three abattoirs respectively 60, 145 and 150 people were laid off. In another abattoir in New South Wales 50 people were laid off.

This has gone on since mid-November last year. We are talking about the charges that went through this House and which were supported by every party, except the Australian Democrats. The reason those charges have caused this situation is very obvious. The industry does not have the capacity to pay. The money is not there, yet charges are still being levied and are still increasing. The sole reason the Australian Democrats are supporting the deferral of this legislation is not for any of the reasons that have been bandied around to try to tart up the operation. We are supporting it solely to keep this whole business on the political agenda, because people are losing jobs and abattoirs are closing down all over this country. The Australian Democrats believe that that is sufficient reason to keep the issue on the boil. We are keen to achieve that by whatever means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's theme today is to say very meekly that all it is doing is validating an earlier regulation or action. It is a theme that may appear to be very plausible and very simple at the outset. But the real crunch is that it would have been okay, had it not been for the unprecedentedly high increases in charges contained in the last Budget. It is these unreasonable charges, this victimisation which has been levied against the primary industry sector, which are the cause of this debate today and of the action that has been proposed by Senator Scott. This implies a rendering unto Caesar of the things that are Caesar's, no matter how vicious, discriminatory or significant they may be in relation to employment and unemployment. I remind Senator Tate that it is the role of an Opposition to point out to the Government the shortcomings of its legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it is a tragedy that the Government did not have the foresight or the courage to conduct an inquiry into this matter before embarking upon this action because, despite all the warnings not only within this place but right throughout every State of Australia, it did not foresee the consequences of its action. It is far too late for the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, to now seek an inquiry and report by 1 May. We hope only that in time the Government will recognise this as another one of its mistakes. We appeal to it, in the same way as it changed its mind and backed down on the assets test, to back down on this particularly vicious imposition which is being placed upon the primary industries of Australia.

I think that every farmer in Australia, every abattoir owner and every worker in those abattoirs, had they been listening to this debate earlier when Senator Walsh spoke, would have not only been concerned but also would have been very worried at the severity and the nature of the Government's response. The viciousness of Senator Walsh's comments which were directed to those very people must be a matter of concern that really sends chills down their spines. I think that ever since the Federal Labor Government came to office its whole approach, from the mini-Budget in May, right through to the Budget and what is transpiring in the Senate today, indicates its lack of understanding of primary industry and of the repercussions of its actions.

Earlier in this debate we heard about the wide-spread lay-offs, the short-times , the dismissals, the problems and the lack of profitability of the meat industry. In the past four months two major meat works in Tasmania have ceased operation because of the rise in export fees. Senator Boswell and my other colleagues have indicated what has happened in Queensland and in the other States. But it is quite typical. The problem does not just exist in one area where one could ride it out politically if one wanted to. The ramifications for the Australian Labor Party of its actions will be very widespread.

Prior to this increase in inspection charges, export abattoirs in Tasmania killed 80 per cent of Tasmanian cattle and 70 per cent of Tasmanian sheep. The spin-off effects of this disastrous imposition will be widespread throughout the community and will include restructuring, dislocation, unemployment and financial losses to employees, to companies and right across the board. Now export abattoirs in Tasmania kill only 20 per cent of cattle and 30 per cent of sheep. These figures are quite chilling. Why are not more members of the Australian Labor Party taking up this matter in their Caucus and in the electorates? They have deserted the primary producers. They have deserted the unionists working in the abattoirs.

The Budget increased the inspection charge for cattle from $1.80 to $5.40 and for sheep from 18c to 54c, a tremendous increase, a 200 per cent rise in meat inspection charges. Earlier speakers referred to the disparity in income movements in the primary industry sector. Small farmers are really battling at the moment. Day after day the Labor Government takes credit for the recovery taking place in primary industry. That recovery is very narrowly based although it is in a very significant sector-the wheat industry. But the bonanza in the wheat industry is a result of the ending of the drought. Other sectors of primary industry are really battling, particularly small primary producers. The days of the small family farm have almost ended. These sorts of charges are making it more and more difficult. As each abattoir closes down, stock will have to be transported further to other abattoirs, thus increasing costs along the line. It is a tragedy. The time allocated by an inspector to inspect a beast makes these charges higher than those charged by a doctor for inspecting a patient for the same time. These sorts of comparisons show that it is quite ridiculous to have such high and unsubstantiated costs in the meat industry.

The industry has major problems. There is a need to alter the whole arrangement . Producers have supported certain changes put forward by the Department of Primary Industry, including the need for a single national inspection service; the use of agencies under contract to the Commonwealth where appropriate, particularly in remote areas; a strongly decentralised management system; the development of a base domestic standard for the registration of premises; a fee for service charging system; an electronic information and communications system ; the modification of security procedures; the integrity of new inspection services to be established; the reappointment of existing staff to the new service on the basis of merit; and so on. There is a need for a new overall legislative framework.

In the early days of the Hawke Government the cry of the Minister for Primary Industry was that he could not get his ideas through Cabinet because he was not a member of Cabinet. The situation has now well and truly changed. We are not seeing from the Cabinet the solutions which are urgently required. We only hope that the Government recognises in time that it has made a mistake and will alter these abominable levies. A lot of credit has been taken by the Government for a recovery which was the result of the ending of the drought, but that recovery has been very narrowly based. The meat industry is really in trouble. Apart from the increased charges, a further problem has been the level of export market prices. These increases in charges make it all the more difficult to export. More often that not, the level of productivity in the industry is appallingly low. This has caused restructuring of the industry, mergers and amalgamations. This Government might say that this is a good thing which will make the industry more competitve. What is it doing? It is causing lay-offs, loss of employment. It is a hard Labor Government which deliberately sets out to sack people within the meat industry.

When Hawke was in Japan he talked about a restructuring of manufacturing industry. He said that there would be tragedies, lay-offs, et cetera. Fortunately in that case a few of his backbenchers stood up for manufacturing industry. But where are the people standing up for the primary industries? Where are the backbenchers to stand up for the meat workers? They are completely silent. They are apathetic. I challenge them one and all to speak up on this issue and to do something for a vital industry which means so much to Australia. We do not appreciate that Australian agriculture and mining are now responsible for 85 per cent of export earnings. What did Senator Tate say? He said that they should pay the charges required by law. He fails to recognise that the primary industry sector will produce 50 per cent or more of export income this year. The primary industry sector is Australia's most important industry. It needs government assistance and government recognition. It cannot carry the continuous attacks that have been levelled at it by this government. Each Australian farmer produces food for approximately 70 people a year. This compares with only 59 people in the United States and 19 people in Western Europe with its heavy subsidisation of agriculture. We have a very efficient primary industry sector, but it is continually under attack. To realise that one need only look at the mini-Budget, the last Budget and what is happening in this debate today.

There is vast potential for technology to improve production further. But what has the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) said about it? He is not interested in applying this technology to the rural sector. He talks about new industries, sunrise industries, and so on. It is about time we started to apply it to some problems. The whole concept of wage indexation and the attitude towards costs are having a frightening effect on the cost structure of Australian industry. We all know that every increase in wage costs is ultimately fed back to the primary industry sector. While it is true that there has been some reduction in the inflation rate in Australia, let us look at the inflation rates of our major competitors. In the United States of America it is one-third of our rate and in Japan it is only 1.8 per cent. Yet we are trying to compete with them and to sell our beef to them.

What did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) do when he was in Korea and Japan? He disregarded the vital interests of the beef producers. What came out of his trip to Japan and Korea as a result was a possible loss of exports to those vital countries. Again he was completely uninterested in and uninformed about the subject. That is not surprising. Even when he was in China he tried to make deals with the Chinese without referring beforehand to the major supplier, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. This is the sort of off-the-cuff decision making that is taking place in Australia. The Prime Minister is playing at brinkmanship. He gets brilliant ideas and then forces the Cabinet to go along with them. Then, maybe if there is enough resurgence of opposition within the community, as there was about the assets test, he says, 'We back down; we have made a mistake'.

Let the Government come forth straight away and acknowledge its mistake on this issue and rectify the matter in the interests of the primary industries, in the interests of the people working in the abattoirs, and in the interests of all those small towns around Australia that do not necessarily have a member of Parliament living in them. Had this dislocation occurred in the suburbs of Sydney or in Wollongong, we would have heard a little more about it. People out in the bush can be forgotten. They are the forgotten people of Australia. At the next election all these people who have been selectively knocked off will rally. I support Senator Scott's proposition that this matter be deferred. We just cannot afford to pass so quickly legislation of this nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to enter this debate, and my name was not on the list of speakers, but I was provoked by the ignorance of Senator Walsh and Senator Tate and the Australian Democrat spokesman on this matter. SPEECH.PARA: I understand what the Bill is about. I understand that it applies up to the events on 21 November 1983. —We are talking about an industry which, as Senator Watson said, is one of the major export earners for Australia. SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Labor Party are notorious as being the financial mismanagers of the Australian economy. They spend far more than they earn in every year-Mr Wran , Mr Cain, Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and all people of that kidney. They look at all the charges when they come into office and then raise them by 20 per cent, 60 per cent or a few hundred per cent in an attempt to balance their books. They never look at what they are doing and at how it is being done. They never ask whether it is a necessary field for the Federal Government to be in. They never ask whether the task, if it is necessary, is being done in the most financially efficient way that it can be done. Instead, it is open cheque books and a raid on the tax that makes Robin Hood look like a boy scout.

Because this legislation is in place we have seen a lift in the beef export levy, from $1.80 to $5.40 in the first year of the Labor Government. We have an admission from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the Budget Speech that the $5.40 represents only 50 per cent of the meat inspection charge. In other words, he is saying that the true cost of inspecting a carcass is $10.80.

I am glad that Senator Tate has just re-entered the chamber because I am about to refer to him. He made the statement, in complete ignorance, that it was only a small lift, and he followed the statement on this matter by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). Mr Kerin went on record as saying that the lift of $3.60, from $1.80 to $5.40, was only about one per cent of the value of the beast. That is the gross value of the beast. The point about which we are talking is that the producer, the person who sends the beast to the abattoir, will pay $5.40. It is certainly not one per cent to him. It is hard to put a figure on it, but one is looking at a figure, a true cost, greater than 20 per cent, because what one must do is relate the cost of the meat export levy to the net profit of the producer. There is a world of difference between the profit that the producer makes and the actual value of the beast at auction. That is the point that the Labor Party does not seem to be able to understand. We are talking about a charge now which probably represents nearly 20 per cent, or more , of the profitability to the producer in growing that beast.

Senator Tate misses the point. It is not a matter of arguing about whether we should charge the producer 50 per cent or something like that. We are talking about whether we have the most efficient inspection process. We have to have an inspection process. There is no argument about that. In an export sugar market, we must be known as a reliable supplier, in the way in which the sugar industry is known. We know that the quality of Australian export meets very tight tolerances year in and year out. For any export market that we have, we must meet those standards. So let us have no argument about the need for an export inspection service.

However, we do not need a service which costs us $10.80 per beast and, more importantly, we do not need a service that is imposed upon the industry by a government without respect to cost. That is precisely what the present Government does in so many other ways. For example, in respect of cost recovery in the aviation industry, it is argued that such and such a percentage of cost should be recovered from the users. Again, that takes no account of the users' interests and needs and the way that they would see that service being run if it were to be run in the most efficient way. To put this cost into perspective, we might look at the figure of $10.80. It is comparable with the figure for a general consultation by a medical practitioner for a human patient. The medical practitioner has to pay the rent and the light bill, he has to amortise his equipment, he has to pay his staff and pay holiday pay, workers' compensation, superannuation and all the rest, and he has to make a profit; and yet he can still examine someone for about $10. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney-General recall yesterday describing the material in the Age tapes as 'completely unauthenticated'? Does he recall saying on a television program this morning that it was 'almost certainly the case that a great many of the conversations between the parties in question did take place in some form or another'? He further said:

QUESTION.PARA: Certainly it is very difficult to contest in any root and branch way the authenticity of the 11 conversations that are the subject of specific content of the four tapes.

Does the statement that the Attorney-General made this morning, taken in the context of his actions in appointing a Special Prosecutor and a joint police task force and in referring matters in the tapes to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and to Mr Redlich, more accurately reflect the state of authenticity of the tapes rather than his political statement of yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start, nothing at all follows from the handing over of the material to appropriate investigating authorities. Mr Creighton Burns, the editor of the Age, seems to have made much, in his own replies to the criticism I have made of the performance of the Age, of the fact that the material has been quickly and promptly handed over to a variety of appropriate investigating authorities. That, of course, implies nothing as to the authenticity or the ultimate evidentiary status of the material in question.

ANSWER.PARA: If ever any serious allegations are made, whether by way of hearsay or in any other form, they are, of course, referred to the appropriate authorities for investigation and report. That is exactly what has happened here. Absolutely nothing should be assumed about the status of the material from that natural and responsible government reaction.

The material in question falls into two categories-first of all, four tapes containing a total, as I recall it, of 11 conversations; and, in addition, something like 524 pages of material divided up into six bundles which between them contain just on 3,000 conversations or summaries of conversations.

I certainly concede, as I did this morning, that it would be very difficult to argue that the tapes themselves constitute a complete fabrication in the sense of no conversation of that kind ever taking place. I would be very surprised if the level of sophistication of even the most ill-motivated people around the place was such as to enable them to produce tapes of that order containing, on the face of it, conversations between people whose voices, perhaps, are recognisable to those who know them. But it certainly does not follow from that that every last bit of content of those tapes is to be regarded as authentic. Indeed, in that sense those tapes are wholly unauthenticated.

It is very easy indeed, as we know from everything we have read or been briefed about, to manipulate or tamper with tapes electronically in order to delete strategic words or to rearrange the flow of particular words or responses in such a way as to create a wholly different impression from that which was intended by the participants.

So there are very real questions about the authenticity of the tapes even if one accepts, as I do, that it is more likely than not that those conversations occurred between the parties in question. The question of authenticity is, of course, now the subject of a very careful examination of a technical kind. I am simply not in a position yet to report upon the outcome of that examination.
The written material has a different status altogether. There is simply no ground whatsoever for accepting the authenticity of any particular conversation or purported conversation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or rejecting.

—I accept that the matter is at large and it is on the basis of the matter being at large that it has been referred to the appropriate authorities for investigation and report in order to determine whether there is any independent or extrinsic evidentiary basis on which an investigation can go forward or, if an investigation does go forward, on which it might reveal something.

ANSWER.PARA: Everything I have said in this respect has been totally self-consistent. I do not want to be taken in any way as resiling from the very forceful statements I made yesterday about the thoroughly dubious authenticity of the material in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Resources and Energy confirm the accuracy of a report in the Age yesterday? The report stated:

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the report in the Age is not entirely accurate. Apparently it refers to a meeting of the London Dumping Convention which was held between 20 and 24 February. I am advised that the Convention could not agree on whether, within its legal ambit, it could cover the question of subsurface ocean dumping of wastes. Therefore, it would appear that the report that the group of 37 nations has blocked such a proposal, while correct in substance is not correct in precise detail. —Like Senator Coates, I believe the term 'dependent female' applied when there is a male partner. Such a relationship is not only inappropriate but is also quite ridiculous. Judge Fitzgerald, in a Federal Court judgment in October last year or the year before last in what was known as the Linehan case, said that he suspected also that the term was offensive to many people. I am pleased to say that I and my Department at the moment are removing the term from the Act and, as soon as possible, probably this session, I would expect, when we introduce a Social Security Amendment Bill which includes technical amendments of this type, and will replace it with terminology consistent with the terms used in the Sex Discrimination Bill which was passed through this place in 1983. It will make no practical difference to the payments made to such people, but it will remove the misleading description from the situation. I do not know about desexing and whether that is a good term for what we are doing to the legislation, but we are certainly trying to remove discrimination from the legislation.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Why was it necessary for the Attorney and the head of his Department to have two meetings with the judge referred to in the Age tapes? Was there some matter left over from the first interview on 15 February which required clarification at the second meeting on 25 February? Apart from the Attorney, the judge and Mr Pat Brazil, was anyone else present at either meeting? Finally, how long did each meeting last? Was the judge played the tape recordings at either meeting?

—There was a matter which had not been discussed at the first meeting on which it did seem appropriate to have the judge's response in the light of other material that I had received, including questions that had been raised about the technical authenticity of the tapes by Ms Mary Gaudron in her opinion which did justify a second meeting. Each meeting took about 20 minutes to half an hour, no more than that. No other persons were present except myself, Mr Brazil and the judge in question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Is the Minister aware that during the recent Richmond by- election the Commonwealth Electoral Officer for Richmond ruled that only two scrutineers for each candidate would be allowed at each polling place when the votes were counted. As some polling places had more than two polling booths, was this ruling a breach of the Commonwealth Electoral Act? If that was the case, will the Minister ensure that it does not happen in the future?

—I have heard of the matter to which Senator Sibraa refers. It is obviously one that gives rise to concern on the part of the Government. I will arrange with the Special Minister of State to investigate the circumstances and I will endeavour to produce a reply for Senator Sibraa by tomorrow.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, follows a question asked by Senator Hearn about the Tolpuddle Martyrs, who were convicted 150 years ago next Monday. Is it not a fact that the initiative for the establishment of a plaque to commemorate the Tolpuddle Martyrs was taken in 1970 by the then Secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, one R. W. B. Harradine? Is it not also a fact that, given that George Loveless was a Methodist lay preacher, the TTLC contacted the Victorian and Tasmanian Methodist conference on the occasion of their meeting in Tasmania and took that opportunity to have the plaque unveiled at the old Trades Hall? Is it not also a fact that the plaque now resides at the new Trades Hall in Newtown? Is it not also a fact that it is not likely to be shifted from that site, given that the same previous Secretary of the TTLC is a life trustee of that Trades Hall? Do not all of these facts show a gross ignorance on the part of members not only of this chamber but also of the media who state that the Tolpuddle Martyrs have never been recognised in that State? Finally, I ask the Minister why members of the Government, including himself and Senator Hearn, voted to have this Parliament meet next Monday, which is Labour Day in Tasmania? I repeat: The Parliament can meet, but it cannot expect me to come here on Labour Day.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anybody who knows anything about the history of trade unionism would accord the Tolpuddle Martyrs a premier position in that history because, against the opposition of conservative governments, they pioneered the right of legal trade union activity. Of course, they were given long penalties and transported to Australia in shocking conditions. They were treated harshly during that transportation. However, they were in the main-if my knowledge of history is correct-Methodist activists and, in my view, they played a fairly significant part in helping to pioneer the ideas of trade unionism in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose that I can only take as fact Senator Harradine's assertion that he did something about this matter in 1970. I do not think I can contradict that statement on the public record. It is a matter of some regret if a dispute exists between the old and new Trades Hall in Tasmania. I do not believe any group, person or building is entitled to own such historic objects as the plaque which commemorates the Tolpuddle Martyrs. However, as I indicated to Senator Hearn, I am not privy to details of the current faction fighting which might involve this issue. Certainly, my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr John Brown, would want to play some part in having the plaque properly recognised and placed. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, who will recall the commitment made at the last election to provide students with 'hands on' experience in the new computer based technologies. Finally, in particular, would the Minister agree-
—Why don't you write your own questions?
—I beg your pardon?
—Order! The honourable senator should direct his question through the Chair.
—Mr President, I think-
—I ask you to ignore interjections and direct your question through the Chair.

—I will do my best, Mr President. In particular, would the Minister agree that the provision of suitable software by such excellent organisations as the Elizabeth Computer Centre in Hobart is as important as the placing of hardware in schools?

ANSWER.PARA: I had the opportunity of visiting the Elizabeth Computer Centre in Tasmania last week. Clearly, it is now important for us to implement our commitment on computer education in a flexible way so that States such as Tasmania which have advanced beyond needing additional hardware and are making a great deal of progress in developing actual educational and teacher development programs will not miss out on any moneys allocated under the program. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. —I call the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and ask the Minister to keep her answer brief.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear that the Opposition is not interested in the major initiatives which will affect virtually all primary school and secondary school children in this country, which will make many more places in higher education available and which will address the long neglected needs of Aboriginal students , students from different ethnic backgrounds and girls and women in our society.
